content: The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002, also known as the Act, increases penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for mail fraud, wire fraud, and securities fraud under Section 1348 of title 18, United States Code. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933. Offenders can be fined or imprisoned for up to 25 years. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933. The act also includes provisions for tampering with records or impeding official proceedings, with penalties of up to 20 years imprisonment. Additionally, there are amendments to the Federal Sentencing Guidelines. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to promptly review and consider new sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud. This includes providing enhancements for officers or directors of publicly traded corporations who commit fraud. The Commission must also submit policy recommendations to Congress for combating these offenses. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, ensuring seriousness of offenses and consistency with other directives. Guidelines should account for circumstances that justify exceptions and ensure adequacy of offense levels for obstruction of justice cases. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, ensuring seriousness of offenses and consistency with other directives. Guidelines should also address situations where documents are destroyed or fabricated, increase offense levels for fraud with over 50 victims, make necessary changes to sentencing guidelines, and align with the purposes of sentencing as outlined in the law. The Commission is urged to act promptly, within 120 days, to implement these guidelines or amendments. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include claims for violation of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of any security as nondischargeable debts. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, makes claims for violation of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of any security as nondischargeable debts. This includes judgments, orders, settlement agreements, damages, fines, penalties, restitutionary payments, disgorgement payments, attorney fees, costs, or other payments owed by the debtor. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a new section requiring corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. The certification must confirm the accuracy of the financial statements in representing the issuer's operations and financial condition. Failure to comply with this requirement may result in criminal penalties. The new section in Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code imposes fines and imprisonment for violations. Willful violations can result in higher penalties. SEC. 7 introduces penalties for attempts and conspiracies to commit offenses against the United States. SEC. 8 increases criminal penalties under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 8 amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to increase criminal penalties, raising the fine to $5,000,000 and maximum imprisonment to 20 years. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to allow the Commission to issue a temporary freeze order when investigating possible violations involving publicly traded securities. The Commission can petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow payments in an interest-bearing account for 45 days. The order can only be entered after notice and a hearing, unless impracticable or contrary to the public interest. The temporary order becomes effective immediately. The temporary order issued by the Commission becomes effective immediately, served to the parties involved, and remains enforceable for 45 days unless modified by a court. Extensions can be granted for up to an additional 45 days, not exceeding a total of 90 days. The court can also determine violations during this process. If an issuer or person is charged with violations of securities laws before a temporary order expires, the order stays in effect until legal proceedings conclude. The affected party can petition the court for review. If the issuer or person is not charged with violations of securities laws before the temporary order expires, the escrow will terminate, and disputed payments will be returned with interest. Technical Amendment: Section 21C(c)(2) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended by replacing "This" with "paragraph (1)". SEC. 10. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to give the Commission the authority to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to allow the Commission to ban individuals who have violated regulations from acting as officers or directors of registered issuers. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize those who retaliate against informants providing truthful information to law enforcement officers regarding Federal offenses. Penalties include fines or imprisonment up to 10 years.
